fullText: Beanie Feldstein is not Barbra Streisand, and she never will be, but she brings her own charm and energy to the role of Fanny Brice in this revival of Funny Girl.
dtliExcerpt: Beanie Feldstein is not Barbra Streisand, and she never will be, but she brings her own charm and energy to the role of Fanny Brice in this revival of Funny Girl.
bwwExcerpt: The production recreates the heart and humor of the Ziegfeld Follies and the razzle-dazzle of Broadway in the 1920s in all of its rude comedy and gaudy glory. Mr. Fierstein adds an edge to the story without diminishing any of its values. New songs have been borrowed from the movie version and other sources, moved around in different acts and inserted for emphasis, and sometimes the whole thing moves too fast to digest. One minute Fanny is the awkward girl from Henry Street in Brooklyn, the next

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-majority] | 2/3 models agree: Positive | Claude: Opens with a comparison that sets modest expectations but concludes positively about Feldstein's performance, suggesting the show is worth seeing despite not reaching legendary heights. | Gemini: The review acknowledges Feldstein's charm and energy but also emphasizes that she is not Streisand, suggesting a mixed assessment of her performance and the revival overall. | Kimi: The critic offers a qualified endorsement of Feldstein's performance, acknowledging she cannot match Streisand's iconic original but praising her individual charm and energy, indicating a solid if reserved recommendation.
